articles.headline: No Charges for Chicago Officer in 2014 Shooting of Ronald Johnson
articles.snippet: The announcement followed several weeks of uproar in Chicago over charges for another officer in a separate shooting death, of Laquan McDonald.
articles.abstract: The announcement followed several weeks of uproar in Chicago over charges for another officer in a separate shooting death, of Laquan McDonald.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For days, officials here have faced scathing criticism for taking too long to share what they knew about the death of Laquan McDonald, who was shot 16 times by a police officer in October 2014 as a dashboard video camera captured it all. On Monday, the authorities seemed determined to make a sharply different impression as they released video of another fatal police shooting of a black man from the same month, which has also become a source of contention in the city.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Economist’s Criticism of Federal Reserve Policies Gains Ground
articles.snippet: Hélène Rey contends that emerging markets have become largely powerless to cope with the impact of Fed policies.
articles.abstract: Hélène Rey contends that emerging markets have become largely powerless to cope with the impact of Fed policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many Fed watchers have warned about the upsetting effect Ben S. Bernanke’s aggressive central bank actions have had on emerging markets around the globe.

articles.headline: Killers Were Long Radicalized, F.B.I. Investigators Say
articles.snippet: The husband and wife had been practicing their aim at a target range in the Los Angeles area days before the massacre in California last week.
articles.abstract: The husband and wife had been practicing their aim at a target range in the Los Angeles area days before the massacre in California last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — The couple who carried out the deadly attack that killed 14 people here last week had long been radicalized and had been practicing at a target range days before their murder spree, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said Monday.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Salman Masood and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Donald Trump Calls for Barring Muslims From Entering U.S.
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump called on Monday for the United States to bar all Muslims from entering the country until the nation’s leaders can “figure out what is going on” after the terrorist attacks in San Bernardino, Calif., an extraordinary escalation of rhetor...
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump called on Monday for the United States to bar all Muslims from entering the country until the nation’s leaders can “figure out what is going on” after the terrorist attacks in San Bernardino, Calif., an extraordinary escalation of rhetoric aimed at voters’ fears about members of the Islamic faith.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump called on Monday for the United States to bar all Muslims from entering the country until the nation’s leaders can “figure out what is going on” after the terrorist attacks in San Bernardino, Calif., an extraordinary escalation of rhetoric aimed at voters’ fears about members of the Islamic faith.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Ex-Im Bank Is Reopened, but Big Loans Are Stalled
articles.snippet: The Export-Import Bank, which helps finance overseas trade, was reauthorized by Congress for another four years, ending a five-month impasse. But obstacles to funding larger transactions remain.
articles.abstract: The Export-Import Bank, which helps finance overseas trade, was reauthorized by Congress for another four years, ending a five-month impasse. But obstacles to funding larger transactions remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The announcement on the Export-Import Bank’s website proclaimed in big blue letters “Ex-Im Bank Reauthorized” — but the fight is not over yet for the government’s embattled export credit agency.

articles.headline: Oil Prices Plunge 5% After OPEC Stands Pat
articles.snippet: A variety of factors is behind the price drop, analysts say, but OPEC’s decision on Friday not to tinker with its output, which is now at near-record levels, sent prices into a collapse.
articles.abstract: A variety of factors is behind the price drop, analysts say, but OPEC’s decision on Friday not to tinker with its output, which is now at near-record levels, sent prices into a collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Crude oil prices slid a further 5 percent on Monday to fall to their lowest levels since the 2009 global recession, pummeled by the fading chance that Saudi Arabia would cut production to halt the commodity’s yearlong slide.

articles.headline: Guns in Your 401(k)? The Push to Divest Grows
articles.snippet: Many plans include the stocks of gun manufacturers, but options are growing for investors who do not want the companies in their portfolios.
articles.abstract: Many plans include the stocks of gun manufacturers, but options are growing for investors who do not want the companies in their portfolios.
articles.lead_paragraph: You probably own a stake in a gun manufacturer, whether you know it or not.

articles.headline: U.S. Seeks to Avoid Ground War Welcomed by Islamic State
articles.snippet: The Islamic State has focused on prophetic texts stating that Islam will be victorious after an apocalyptic battle to be set off once Western armies come to the region.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State has focused on prophetic texts stating that Islam will be victorious after an apocalyptic battle to be set off once Western armies come to the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the debate on how best to contain the Islamic State continues to rage in Western capitals, the militants themselves have made one point patently clear: They want the United States and its allies to be dragged into a ground war.

articles.headline: Terrorists Mock Bids to End Use of Social Media
articles.snippet: Politicians and even some technologists say Silicon Valley’s efforts to crack down on the use of social media and other technologies like encryption by terrorists have been toothless.
articles.abstract: Politicians and even some technologists say Silicon Valley’s efforts to crack down on the use of social media and other technologies like encryption by terrorists have been toothless.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the hours after 14 people were killed in San Bernardino, Calif., a familiar voice celebrated the attacks on Twitter: “California, we have already arrived with our soldiers. Decide how to be your end, with knife or bomb.”
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Potential Power Shift as Court Weighs ‘One Person One Vote’
articles.snippet: The voting rights case Evenwel v. Abbott has the potential to shift political power from urban areas to rural ones.
articles.abstract: The voting rights case Evenwel v. Abbott has the potential to shift political power from urban areas to rural ones.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A closely divided Supreme Court on Tuesday struggled to decide “what kind of democracy people wanted,” as Justice Stephen G. Breyer put it during an argument over the meaning of the constitutional principle of “one person one vote.”

articles.headline: Smog So Thick, Beijing Comes to a Standstill
articles.snippet: The poisonous air quality prompted the government to declare a “red alert,” closing schools, forcing motorists to stay off the road and shutting factories.
articles.abstract: The poisonous air quality prompted the government to declare a “red alert,” closing schools, forcing motorists to stay off the road and shutting factories.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Residents across this city awoke to an environmental state of emergency on Tuesday as poisonous air quality prompted the government to close schools, force motorists off the road and shut down factories.

articles.headline: Living a Frontier Dream on the Outskirts of China’s Capital
articles.snippet: On the outskirts of Beijing, more than 1,000 families have settled into a community modeled after an American frontier town, on streets with names like Aspen, Moose and Route 66.
articles.abstract: On the outskirts of Beijing, more than 1,000 families have settled into a community modeled after an American frontier town, on streets with names like Aspen, Moose and Route 66.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, China — Yearning to breathe untainted air, the band of harried urbanites flocked to this parched, wild land, bringing along their dreams of a free and uncomplicated life.

articles.headline: If It Owns a Well or a Mine, It’s Probably in Trouble
articles.snippet: The mining giant Anglo American is cutting its global work force by more than half, while a quarter of a million workers in the global oil and gas industry have already been laid off.
articles.abstract: The mining giant Anglo American is cutting its global work force by more than half, while a quarter of a million workers in the global oil and gas industry have already been laid off.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pain among energy and mining producers worsened again on Tuesday, as one of the industry’s largest players cut its work force by nearly two-thirds and Chinese trade data amplified concerns about the country’s appetite for commodities.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Ian Austen
